member.name: MEMORYSTATUS
member.summary: Contains information about the current state of both physical and virtual memory. The function stores information in aMEMORYSTATUS structure.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwLength
member.summary: The size of theMEMORYSTATUS data structure, in bytes. You do not need to set this member before calling the function; the function sets it.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwMemoryLoad
member.summary: A number between 0 and 100 that specifies the approximate percentage of physical memory that is in use (0 indicates no memory use and 100 indicates full memory use).

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwTotalPhys
member.summary: The amount of actual physical memory, in bytes.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwAvailPhys
member.summary: The amount of physical memory currently available, in bytes. This is the amount of physical memory that can be immediately reused without having to write its contents to disk first. It is the sum of the size of the standby, free, and zero lists.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwTotalPageFile
member.summary: The current size of the committed memory limit, in bytes. This is physical memory plus the size of the page file, minus a small overhead.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwAvailPageFile
member.summary: The maximum amount of memory the current process can commit, in bytes. This value should be smaller than the system-wide available commit. To calculate this value, call and subtract the value of CommitTotal from CommitLimit.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwTotalVirtual
member.summary: The size of the user-mode portion of the virtual address space of the calling process, in bytes. This value depends on the type of process, the type of processor, and the configuration of the operating system. For example, this value is approximately 2 GB for most 32-bit processes on an x86 processor and approximately 3 GB for 32-bit processes that are large address aware running on a system with 4 GT RAM Tuning enabled.

member.name: MEMORYSTATUS.dwAvailVirtual
member.summary: The amount of unreserved and uncommitted memory currently in the user-mode portion of the virtual address space of the calling process, in bytes.
